comment._content: The Chain Bridge Hotel is uniquely situated on a narrow strip of land between the dramatic fast-flowing waters of the River Dee on one side, and the serene Llangollen Canal on the other. Access to the hotel is via a long, narrow drive. Berwyn Station with its famous steam trains is located across the river from the hotel. The chain bridge, from which the hotel takes its name, was originally constructed in 1814 by Exuperious Pickering, a local owner of coal mines and lime kilns, to enable him to take his coal across the river for delivery to Corwen and Bala while avoiding three toll fees over the Llangollen Town Bridge. The original bridge hung from a network of handmade chains, and became the most famous and unique bridge on the river. It was refurbished and strengthened in 1870, rebuilt in 1876, and rebuilt again in 1929. The bridge has been closed due to safety reasons for the past 30 years, however a recent grant from the Heritage Lottery Fund will allow a thorough evaluation of the bridge, and determine the cost to restore it (if further funding is available). The original Chain Bridge Inn was most likely built around the same time as the bridge (c.1814). In the 1870s the Inn was rebuilt and enlarged in the black and white style that can be seen today. The Tudor Bar is situated in the main, 1870, building, and has black and white beams, with an Inglenook fireplace. William Watson (1873-1961), the Liverpool-born champion cylist, racing driver and motoring pioneer, was also interested in hotels, and briefly owned the Chain Bridge Hotel around 1960. Seamus O'Keeffe and his wife Elizabeth, bought the hotel in 2012 for £500,000, and have pledged to fully restore the hotel by the Bicentennial of the hotel in 2014. —Compiled [1 [2] [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] [9]   Chain Bridge Hotel – Then and Now (100+ years later) At some point a major three-story addition was made, significantly increasing the length of the hotel along the river-front. The first floor is an enlarged dining area, with two floors of rooms above. The hotel currently has 36 rooms.   "Chainbridge Hotel (2010)" by Jeff McDonald    "Chain Bridge Hotel (c.1890)"       by LOC
